results.title: Love and anarchy: the wild wild world of Jaimie Leonarder [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Pagan Films, SBS Independent, Karena Slaninka and Brendan Young
results.brief_description: An insightful documentary into the life and background of performer, diversional therapist, broadcaster, street worker, nightclub impresario, film archivist and champion of the marginalised outsider sub-culture, Jaimie Leonarder. His is an amazing story of compassion, obsession and commitment within a culture of outsiders - drug addicts, psychiatric patients, the homeless. His band, the Mu-Mesons, which comprised of ex-psychiatric patients and eccentrics acted as a therapeutical diversion for its members allowing them to perform totally uninhibited, pushing music to its wild limits. The film also explores the relationship between Jaimie and his wife, Aspasia who shares his passion in film collecting and involvement with the outsider community. Through interviews, film excerpts, live band performances and archival footage, director Brendan Young (Three chords and a wardrobe, Boys on film 3) captures the enthusiasm and vitality of this international cult figure who through all his endeavours in the world of the arts and the marginalised, still manages to remain comparatively unknown in his home town Sydney and wider Australia. Contains some b&w footage.

results.title: Love and anarchy = Film d'amore e d'anarchia
results.brief_description: In the chaotic Italy of the 1930s, Tunin (Giancarlo Giannini) is a young peasant radical who goes to the big city in order to assassinate Mussolini. His underground contact is Salome (Mariangela Melato) who is a Madame of a brothel. As in all her film work, Wertmuller combines sexual comedy with a sharp and subversive reworking of socialist and feminist themes. As the film progresses and we see the interaction between prostitutes, anarchists and Fascists, we become less sure of what is real and what is merely artiface in the world of politics. Wertmuller has pioneered a cinema that reveals politics is as much a style as it is didactism, as much performance as it is commitment. The poor foolish Tunin, who believes in love and justice, is the archetype of the Fool. The music is by Nino Rota. Winner of a prize at the 1973 Cannes Film Festival.

results.title: Love among the ruins
results.creator_credit: ABC Video Enterprises, Star Video, Allan Davis and George Cukor
results.brief_description: In London, 1911, a prestigious London barrister (Laurence Olivier) is defending an ageing actress (Katherine Hepburn), from a breach of promise suit brought by a young gigolo who claims she trifled with his affections and reneged on her promise to marry him. The stiff collar barrister and his client were lovers years ago. Hepburn and Olivier give love a touch of class and received Emmy Awards for their performances. Similarly recognised was the sensitive direction by George Cukor (his TV movie debut) and the writing of James Costigan. Co-starring Colin Blakely, Richard Pearson, Joan Sims and Leigh Lawson. Based on the novel by Angela Thirkell.

results.title: Love's Labour Lost
results.brief_description: Ferdinand, King of Navarre, and his friends, Berowne of Biron, Longaville, and Dumain, take an oath to eschew themselves to study for three years. But when the charming princess of France arrives with her three ladies the four gentlemen fall in love with the four ladies. Spying on each other the “academics” discover each other’s perfidy and in good spirit decide that love is a lawful part of all study. Learning that the king of France has died, the ladies are obliged to leave, but not before assigning various penances to their suitors and promising to return in one year.

results.title: Love's a bitch = Amores perros [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Altavista Films, Zeta Film (Mexico) and Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu
results.brief_description: Perhaps the only successful commercial Mexican release in contemporary cinema, “Amores perros” is action-packed and hard-hitting from the first frame. Divided into three separate but overlapping narratives (a la Altman and Tarantino), each explores themes of loss, survival, despair and the constant battle of life and change. The three strands are linked by a horrendous car accident that also symbolises the frenetic and explosive nature of life in this urban jungle. The first story focuses on the young Octavio (played by Gael Garcia Bernal), who is also entangled in the local dog-fighting scene, his infatuation with his sister-in-law, a young mother juggling school and an adulterous, criminal husband. The second centres on supermodel, Valeria (Goya Toldeo), whose life is turned asunder when she is seriously hurt and the strain this places on her relationship with a man who has just left his wife and children for her. Finally, the last and most poetic narrative strand centres on a former political fighter now a homeless, contracted hitman who longs for his family. Hand-held camerawork, fast editing and music inserts work hard to keep the drama intense and frenetic. Thematically, “Amores perros” explores the idea of life as an endless struggle where humans are like ‘animals’ in their sheer attempt to survive. In fact, both ‘dog’ and ‘human’ undergo mutilation and abandonment throughout the film and are pushed to the extreme in their ability to endure a world of hard-knocks. Mexican cinema and television has a long history of melodrama and ‘Amores perros’ clearly emerges from this tradition, infusing strong doses of story melodrama with modern storytelling and edgy stylistics. If its ‘life lessons’ are at times cliched and heavy-handed, the film is still an engaging, commanding experience. In Spanish with English subtitles. Note: Contains violence against animals and human mutilation and carnage.

results.title: Love
results.creator_credit: It's About Time, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Pat Hunder and Garry Dunstan
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
This episode focuses on teenage reactions to love and relationships. Through mini dramatisations, issues such as crushes on teachers, how to be attractive to the opposite sex, romantic fiction and sex-role stereotyping, are examined in a humorous manner. This program aims at validating the experiences of teenagers rather than offering any concrete solutions.

results.title: Loulou [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Action Films, Gaumont-British Instructional, Klaus Hellwig, Yves Gasser and Maurice Pialat
results.brief_description: A middle-class woman (Isabelle Huppert) leaves her safe long-term relationship with her boss (Guy Marchand) for good sex and a socially-marginal existence with a roughly handsome unemployed working-class man (Gerard Depardieu). Shot largely in long handheld takes, the film posits sex as a force that shatters not only class allegiances and established social patterns but even the order represented by conventional narrative structures. Eliciting spontaneous and improvised performances from his actors, Pialat blends a loosely told love story with an acute social observation of the sexual and social mores of France in the seventies. The characters’ actions and behaviours are presented straightforwardly without moralising, enabling an open-ended exploration of the way class differences play out in power relations between the sexes.

results.title: Louisiana story
results.brief_description: Louisiana Story is an enchanting record of the infatuation of a French Cajun boy with the wild landscape of the forest marshes of South Louisiana. With his pet racoon, he hunts, fishes and explores the quiet waterways and larger rivers. When a bulldozer crashes through the reeds he is fascinated by it and goes on to find a floating oil derrick anchored in mid stream with a tower a hundred feet high and a deep plunge into the river bed. The tempo of industrialism is heard as the drill of the oil searches is driven into the depth of the earth. The whole story of the boy’s activities is shown as an enchantment and delightfully portrayed. Photographed by Richard Leacock. Music by Virgil Thompson. Edited by Helen van Dongen.

results.title: Louise Drouin: veterinarian
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Louise Spence and Margaret Wescott
results.brief_description: A portrait of a country veterinarian, working mother, and partner in a thriving practice. In the film, Dr. Drouin shares many facets of her life: at work in her surgery, making “house calls” that take her over a hundred miles from home, and rare moments of relaxation with her husband and child. Articulate and forthright, she talks about the joys and sorrows of being a veterinarian, and how she balances the demands of a busy profession with those of raising a family.
